body: add to whitelist.
Comment #7, has been addressed (Tyrpesafe wrt generalization)

This was in response to comment during IPMC vote for release 0.10.0 requesting it be fixed in next release.  NOTICE files are now identical but left versions in distrib, standalone, etc. folders since referenced separately in corresponding build xml files in case diverge in future.

1) Cache block extensions: First, estimateSizeInMemory and estimateSizeOnDisk are redundant to the existing getInMemorySize and getExactSerializedSize. Second, the interface of the overloaded sliceOperations w/ PartitionedBlock needs cleanup (return type T, both block and pBlock as inputs). I would actually be in favor of removing the second slide altogether (and keep the functionality in PartitionedBlock). Third, please also use T for CacheBlock paramters to these functions to avoid unnecessary modifications of MatrixBlock/FrameBlock. Fourth, the methods for getNewInstance are odd as they need to be called on an existing instance (if they are kept, also change the return type to T). Can't we create a simple method UtilFunctions that does the same via java reflection? 

2) CacheableData extensions: Please change members/APIs from BroadcastObject(CacheBlock) to BroadcastObject(T) to make it type-safe.

3) FrameObject: Replace the change in FrameObject.readBlobFromHDFS with current head (you need to rebase to the latest code).

4) Codestyle: First, remove unnecessary casts, e.g., after getBlock (e.g., ParameterizedBuiltinSPInstruction). The same applies to any casts like (T[]) (e.g., PartitionedBlock) - this is usually an indicator of a bad API design. Second, please generally try to use short but meaningful variable names - something like 'bDoNotUpdateZeroData' is just unnecessarily convoluted.

5) Input/OutputInfos: see 5 above (e.g., FrameReaderFactory/FrameWriterFactory/InputInfo/OutputInfo/MapReduceTool). 

6) MR Compatibility: Remove the import of scala.Tuple2. You need to be careful not to introduce Spark dependencies into the core block runtime otherwise this would break on MR clusters without Spark libs.

7) Testsuite: First, the R input file handling seems incorrect (name + "Csv") - either use a proper file extension or the same name. Second, remove the BinaryBlockFrame input/output infos from ALL tests (FrameConverterTest/FrameMatrixCasting, see 5). Third, remove commented code from your testclasses - this is more confusing than it helps anybody.
Thank you @gweidner. LGTM.
Note: I did not commit the NOTICE updates since these are not needed. For more information, see [PR180](https://github.com/apache/incubator-systemml/pull/180).
How to use the java code to  save/load  your trained model?????
How to use the java code to save/load your trained model?????

Thanks @Wenpei  for your efforts. Can you also please double check if https://github.com/apache/incubator-systemml/pull/155/files#diff-600376dffeb79835ede4a0b285078036L261 is disabling all the java unit tests: Please see: https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-PullRequestBuilder/435/
Also similarly updated corresponding reuse-glm-predict.dml for JMLC ReuseModelVariablesTest.  Different warnings in other algorithms can be addressed in additional subtask(s) of [SYSTEMML-514].
LGTM. Thank you @gweidner
Note chose not to use new toString or as.scalar since the matrix simply wrapped a single scalar value.  Another option was to delete the print which was invalid for matrix if executed.

LGTM. Thank you @gweidner for fixing the warnings in the main algorithms. This is a big win for new users since we don't want to scare them away with unnecessary warnings.

By any chance, if you are running through the algorithms and testing them, would you mind saving (1) the data generation invocation, and (2) the algorithm invocation (such as $ ./runStandaloneSystemML.sh scripts/algorithms/Univar-Stats.dml -nvargs X=data/haberman.data TYPES=data/types.csv STATS=data/univarOut.mtx)? I would really like our documentation to include examples that a user can copy/paste from the documentation and run ALL our algorithms without having to do any additional work.

Thank you for the review and suggestion!  That's good idea so I'll capture that information and also compare with Algorithms Reference.  For these 2 main algorithms, I ran from unit test cases since the test scripts were identical to scripts/algorithms.

The Algorithms Reference is quite verbose. My hope is to create a small single-paragraph summary of each main algorithm and have an accompanying invocation line that can be copy/pasted and it will run the algorithm with absolutely no tweaking required by the user.
That's even better and would definitely be helpful to end users.  I'll take that approach and provide information as it will be good exercise for me to get familiar with other algorithms too :)

thanks @asurve - just two required fixes; once they are done you could directly push this change.

1) Partitioning-preserving: please change the condition to entire columns only (but arbitrary many, e.g., X[,3:1328] is still partitioning preserving); for rows it would only apply to the first row but that's not worth including.

2) Simplifications Block Filter: The function IsFrameBlockInRange only requires [rl,ru], please remove the cl/cu parameters. Also, remove all block sizes (they are not required and might be even incorrect in case of variable length blocks). Let's remove bclen from UtilFunctions.isInFrameBlockRange and pass frame.getNumRows() as brlen.
LGTM.  Thanks!
Merged!

great - thanks @nishi-t , I would recommend just a few additional cleanups and then we're good to go: 

1) Cox-predict.dml: Please fix the condition >max_event_time (instead of <max_event_time).

2) Style: Could we also globally change any comparison with 0.0 to 0? This PR is a good opportunity to clean this up once and for all.

3) Documentation: Please update the "output" column in https://apache.github.io/incubator-systemml/dml-language-reference.html#operators to "Matrix or Scalar" for the comparison operators and refer to footnotes 1 and 2.

4) Validation DMLSyntacticValidator: I would recommend to move this deprecation check into BuiltinFunctionExpression (ppred validation) to make it independent of the frontend language.
Thank you for your comments @mboehm7, I'm going to fix my PR following the comments.
Launched [Jenkins](https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-OnDemand/182/) build.
addressed for the comments. Could you please review again @mboehm7 .

thanks @nakul02 - couple of comments:

1) Matrix readers: is there a reason why you only modified the parallel binary block reader but not csv, textcell, and mm? I would  recommend to simply modify the MatrixReaderFactory and select the sequential readers if DEFAULT_SPARSEBLOCK is not MCSR. Yes, it might be too pessimistic if the data is dense, but we anyway use MCSR to overcome CSR performance issues on incremental construction (e.g., read of textcell with unordered input cells). 

2) LibMatrixDNN: This is not related to the PR at hand, but I would also call the sequential version for numThreads=1 because there is no point in creating the threadpool for single-threaded execution. Furthermore, right now any exceptions within those  tasks get discarded - please get the set of futures from invokeall and explicitly call get (which will propagate any occurred exceptions). @niketanpansare 

3) LibMatrixDatagen/LibMatrixMult: Please fold the thread-safe condition into the main fallback to sequential execution in order to simplify potential code paths.

4) Matrix Block: We need to make this isThreadSafe method robust against non-allocated sparse blocks (sparseBlock==null).

5) Tests: It would be actually a great idea to use CSR as default sparse block type and run our entire testsuite to reveal any open issues. We've never done that so far. Anyway, if we find anything, we don't need to delay this PR but can solve it separately.

great - thanks @nishi-t this looks already pretty good. Just one final cleanup:

ad 4) Please move the warning to BuiltinFunctionExpression.validateExpression() which allows you to call raiseValidateError(message, true) in the base class in order to ensure consistency of warning messages. With that you can also remove the custom method for warnings (this raises a good point to cleanup the warning messages across syntactic parsers and validation; feel free to file a jira).
Thank you for your review @mboehm7. I fixed the PR.
If my these changes to raise waring look good, I'm going to apply it to the case of other deprecated operator(e.g.  castAsScalar) too.
LGTM - thanks @nishi-t

thanks for the comments @mboehm7,
Fixed 1 & 4.
5) I can send in a test on Jenkins once this PR is in.

2) LibMatrixDNN - Correct me if I am wrong, but I think sequential version is being called for when numThreads is 1. Also the Exceptions are being propagated up. 

3) LibMatrixDataGen - fixed, LibMatrixMult - The check is done when the `output.sparse` flag has been set. The `isThreadSafe()` check cannot be folded into the main fallback for sequential execution in those cases.

Launched [Jenkins](https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-OnDemand/186/) Build.

thanks @nakul02 

ad 2) good - then, I must have overlooked it.
ad 3) well, it would be good if we could also do it for matrix mult; the conditions for sparse output are very simple, meaning we could easily fold them into the fall back condition instead of creating the instance first and checking the instance. If there is a good reason fine, otherwise I would really prefer to have it as simple as possible, especially for something like matrix mult.

@mboehm7 
3) Fixed
I had this question about LibMatrixMult, related to this PR:

In [LibMatrixMult.matrixMultPermute](https://github.com/nakul02/incubator-systemml/blob/master/src/main/java/org/apache/sysml/runtime/matrix/data/LibMatrixMult.java#L488), the output is specifically being set to dense. Thereafter, in [MatrixMultPermuteTask.call](https://github.com/nakul02/incubator-systemml/blob/master/src/main/java/org/apache/sysml/runtime/matrix/data/LibMatrixMult.java#L4294), a check is being made for m2 or ret1 being sparse. If the code in [matrixMultPermuteSparse](https://github.com/nakul02/incubator-systemml/blob/master/src/main/java/org/apache/sysml/runtime/matrix/data/LibMatrixMult.java#L2104) is executed, it would crash because of [this](https://github.com/nakul02/incubator-systemml/blob/master/src/main/java/org/apache/sysml/runtime/matrix/data/LibMatrixMult.java#L2108) line, since before this call, ret1 is already set to dense. `matrixMultPermuteDenseSparse` would never be called because re1 was set to dense.
I understand that the code structure in [MatrixMultPermuteTask.call](https://github.com/nakul02/incubator-systemml/blob/master/src/main/java/org/apache/sysml/runtime/matrix/data/LibMatrixMult.java#L4294) mimcs the code structure in the [serial version](https://github.com/nakul02/incubator-systemml/blob/master/src/main/java/org/apache/sysml/runtime/matrix/data/LibMatrixMult.java#L445). Is there any other reason for the code to look like that?
I ask because, in [matrixMultPermuteDense](https://github.com/nakul02/incubator-systemml/blob/master/src/main/java/org/apache/sysml/runtime/matrix/data/LibMatrixMult.java#L2013), ret2 is begin allocated and being operated on. As it stands right now, this will not crash because it allocates a Dense block, which is thread safe, but it is something to be aware of for future code modifications.

Launched [Jenkins](https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-OnDemand/187/) build.

that's a great catch @nakul02 - we should fix the sparsity condition in matrixMultPermute(..., int k). 

The reason why it never showed up so far is that we primarily compile these pmm operators in MR/Spark to avoid materializing diag(v) and there pmm is always executed as single-threaded block operations. However, there are potential corner cases where after recompile pmm is pushed into CP and hence we should fix that asap. Thanks.

Thanks, @nishi-t!  I ran the PyDML implicit slicing bounds tests locally ([PyDMLImplicitSlicingBounds](https://github.com/apache/incubator-systemml/blob/master/src/test/java/org/apache/sysml/test/integration/functions/indexing/PyDMLImplicitSlicingBounds.java)), and all were successful.  Let's let the rest of the test suite run in [test build 451](https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-PullRequestBuilder/451/), and then I can merge it.

ad 3) LibMatrixAgg and LibMatrixMult: Did you update the PR? There are still several instances in LibMatrixAgg and LibMatrixMult with multiple fallbacks to sequential execution - let's please consolidate them. For simplicity don't add these checks whenever it is always dense. Also, I would recommend some static check in MatrixBlock like isThreadSafe(boolean sparse) that would allow you to directly fold these checks into the existing fallback conditions.

6) The License header of LibMatrixDNN has been corrupted. Also the formatting of some conditions have been unnecessarily changed (e.g., ReaderBinaryBlockParallel) - please simply revert with head.

7) MatrixBlock: Please delete DEFAULT_SPARSEBLOCK_THREADSAFE as it is a potential source of inconsistencies and check instead SparkBlock.TypeMCSR. Thanks.
Can an Admin verify this patch?
Tests passed.
Merged.  Thanks, @nishi-t!

3) Fixed, I think having the isThreadSafe check even when dense is alright. If later for performance reasons, we wanted to make dense blocks thread unsafe, these checks would help.

6) Fixed

7) IMHO, DEFAULT_SPARSEBLOCK_THREADSAFE is the better approach than to always check against MCSR. 
If someone were to change the DEFAULT_SPARSEBLOCK type, he would correspondingly change the DEFAULT_SPARSEBLOCK_THREADSAFE since they are very closely located.
Also, later if someone were to make COO or CSR threadsafe, or introduce another SparseBlock implementation which is thread safe and change the default to that, a check against MCSR would be useless.

Also, a little comment - on examining LibMatrixMult, there seem be many "Magic Numbers".
blocks sizes and cache line sizes and such are hard-coded in guard statements. Maybe as a later PR, these could be made class level final static integers?
LGTM.
Thank you @dusenberrymw. I'll merge.

8) LibMatrixDatagen: Please, fix the check in LibMatrixDataGen. This check needs to happen either after reset(..., lsparse) or much better directly on lsparse and the static isThreadSafe.

Remark) I still don't see a good usecase for all this unnecessary complexity (indirections via redundant constants, separated sparse=false + check for isThreadSafe(sparse) + allocation). While CSR is great in terms of memory efficiency for read-only data, it has severe performance problems on incremental construction (read and any operations that appends cells to the output). Accordingly, we will not change the default sparse representation.
thanks @nmanchev this already looks pretty good - just one minor request: could you please rename the rbm_run.dml to something like rbm-predict.dml to make clear that it's the scoring script for rbm?

thanks @asurve - couple of comments:

1) Fix frame mappend rbind: This function would create incorrect results for multiple rhs blocks (rhs blocks never emitted). Also, remove the unncessary code paths (e.g., MapSideAppendFunction else)

2) Fix frame mappend comments: The comment on partitioning preserving operations is misleading, the number of blocks are just indirectly relevant - the actual question is if keys change or not

3) Simplification frame mappend: Since rbind and cbind have different functions, let's simplify the code and remove any cbind checks from these functions. You might also want to rename them accordingly.

4) Fix frame rappend rbind: This instruction only supports cbind (would create incorrect results on rbind). Further, in case of misaligment (variable sized lhs/rhs blocks) it would also create incorrect results for cbind.

5) For frame rbind, we should always compile an rappend (union/and remapping of rhs blocks). Or do you have a good usecase where we want to still compile a broadcast based plan?

6) Tests: Please, pick fixed sparsity values for both lhs and rhs - otherwise the tests become non-deterministic which created problems in the past. Also the formatting of commonAppendTest needs fixing (mix of space/tab indentation)

7) Test scripts: There are only tests for cbind - please add the tests for rbind as well (which will help to fix the issues of incorrect results).
@mboehm7 thanks for your feedback. Renamed as suggested.

Thanks Matthias for the feedback, I addressed the comments you specified. The only comment I am not sure I understood was "Also use something like 'tmp' as the name for the new ternary operator". Could you please elaborate more on what you meant by that?

thanks @tgamal - I really just meant the "name" parameter of the newly constructed hop during rewrites - having something short that also indicates its automatic construction would simplify debugging.
thanks @mboehm7 - I updated the name. Kindly let me know if you suggest further changes

thanks @tgamal - there are just two minor cleanups remaining:

1) Please remove the "oldFlag = OptimizerUtils.ALLOW_ALGEBRAIC_SIMPLIFICATION" and one of the two "OptimizerUtils.ALLOW_ALGEBRAIC_SIMPLIFICATION = rewrites" assignments in testRewriteAxpy as they are redundant.

2) Please add an additional check to your rewrite. We should NOT apply the rewrite if DMLScript.rtplatform=RUNTIME_PLAN.Hadoop or DMLScript.rtplatform=RUNTIME_PLAN.Hybrid as the physical operator is not implemented for hadoop yet. The check is sufficient - once this feature is in, I will add the MR support but we cannot break the testsuite.

thanks @asurve - this looks already much better - just some minor cleanups.

8) moveData in CacheableData: Please simplify this functionality (the writeBlobFromRDDToHDFS should already be covered by export).

9) VariableCPInstruction: Also simply the unnecessary casts and branches when calling moveData (simply getCachableData and dirctly call moveData on it).

10) FrameAppendMSPInstruction.processInstruction: Modify the runtime exception to use opcodes; otherwise this exception message is incomprehensible for users.

11) MapSideAppendPartitionFunction: Please, simplify the implementation, i.e., remove the _cbind member variable and its use.

NOTE: In the future, please rename the existing instruction to the new matrix instruction and create a new base class. By deleting the code from the existing instruction and reinserting it into a new matrix instruction, you detach the file history. I'm not asking you to modify this in the current PR, just something to keep in mind.

ad 10) You did change the message to "Opcode " + instOpcode + " not supported/required with FrameAppendM, instead use FrameAppendR for this opcode processing." which would resolve to "Opcode mappend not supported/required with FrameAppendM, instead use FrameAppendR for this opcode processing." - please change to "Append type rbind not supported for frame mappend, instead use rappend".
Can an Admin verify this patch?

LGTM, @deroneriksson - could you please merge this?
Thanks @ahmaurya

Welcome to Apache SystemML, @ahmaurya! Thank you for working on this.  Thank you @nakul02 for reviewing.

Unfortunately, I don't think I will be able to merge this. Changing the extensions from .html to .md will allow a user to browse through the raw md files on the GitHub project site (https://github.com/apache/incubator-systemml/blob/master/docs/algorithms-reference.md). However, it will break the links on the generated GitHub documentation site (http://apache.github.io/incubator-systemml/algorithms-reference.html) and any locally generated documentation site (docs/_site/algorithms_reference.html). Since jekyll uses the raw md files to generate a static html documentation site, we need to keep the extensions as html.

Since Jekyll generates HTML files, it should be its job to link them properly as well, perhaps using a plugin as advised here: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/25826770/jekyll-using-links-to-internal-markdown-files Anyway, this issue is not important to consume your time and mine. I am closing this thread out. Thanks.

Thank you @ahmaurya. I think it is a bit frustrating that this issue is not handled automatically by Jekyll and GitHub. If you would like to do a contribution that allows links to work both in the raw project view and the generated documentation site, I would be very happy to merge. Note that a plugin requires updating of the licenses in the project artifacts that would contain the plugin.

thanks @asurve - let's do just some additional cleanups: 

1) Avoid shuffle: Please remove the sorting from binaryBlockToDataFrame. A data frame is just a bag of rows, which allows us to do a simple map-side conversion without shuffle.

2) Efficiency row deep copy: Use a RowFactory.create(tmp.clone) instead of array allocation plus loop-based copy. This applies to BinaryBlockToDataFrameFunction and RowGenerator. Also, please double check that this is really required, i.e., have a look at RowFactory and see if the passed arrays are not already copied under the covers.

3) Code style: Globally change pre-increments ++i to post-increments i++ for consistency with the rest of the code base!

NOTE: I'll deliver some changes to the csvToBinaryBlock converter tomorrow - so please merge carefully.
RowFactory keeps references to array, so need to copy. I cloned it now instead of copy per comments. Addressed all comments.

thanks for sharing the numbers @nakul02 

1) Could you please provide the numbers for both CPU_CSR and CPU_MCSR, incl sparse matrix-vector products as well? Also do these numbers show the time after JIT (how many warmup runs, how many repetitions)?
2) It would be good to separate the experiments into two scenarios: transfer+compute as well as transfer + repeated compute on device (especially for the memory-bandwidth-bound sparse matrix-vector multiply).
3) Regarding the actual pull-request: the introduced getValueArray() and getColumnIndexArray() in the individual sparse block implementations are redundant to the existing values() and indexes().

done.

@mboehm7 -
My experiments were run like so:
A simple dml file was written to do sparse matrix multiplication
sparse.dml -

```
m=$1
k=$2
n=$3
X = rand(rows=m, cols=k, min=0, max=4, pdf="uniform", sparsity=0.3)
Y = rand(rows=k, cols=n, min=0, max=4, pdf="uniform", sparsity=0.3)
if (1 == 1) {
    S <- X %*% Y
}
print (as.scalar(S[1,1]))
```

A simple bash script was used to run tests for various values of M=N & K

```
#!/bin/bash

M="100 200 400 800 1600 3200 6400 12800 25600 51200"
K="100 200 400 800 1600 3200 6400 12800 25600 51200"


for i in $M
    do
        for j in $K
            do
                echo "M = $i, K = $j, N = $i" >> OUT
                bin/systemml sparse.dml -stats -args $i $j $i 2>> OUT
                bin/systemml sparse.dml -stats -gpu force=true -args $i $j $i 2>> OUT
            done
    done
```

I then process the `OUT` file with a python script and generate the graphs using matplotlib.

1) The numbers in the graph do not have any repetition runs and do not have warmup runs.
But I can modify the sparse.dml file to put the matrix multiplication in a loop. 
Also, I can do this for a sparse matrix vector product (by setting N=1).
Will this be enough?

2) With this particular experiment, what exactly are we trying to answer?
In this PR, there is instrumentation to measure the transfer of data from device to host and vice versa. Will that suffice?

3) The`values(int r)` and `indexes(int r)` in `SparseBlockCSR` and `SparseBlockCOO` are supposed to return the column indices/values of row r, but they don't. Instead they return the entire array itself. The argument `r` is ignored.
Assuming this is fixed in a later version, I thought introducing a dedicated getter method to get the internal members would be safer.

1) ok, then I would strongly recommend to run multiple iterations (depending on datasize, at least 20) as the difference between initial performance and after JIT is roughly 2-3x for dense, 5x for sparse. Usually, it's a good idea to instrument the core block multiply and run it with gc:verbose to exclude buffer pool times and runs were garbage collection interfered with the timing.

2) well, right now we're still in a stage were we first need to really understand the basic characteristics. Personally, I would be interested in a couple of things: How close to peak PCIe transfer speeds to we get? How close to peak GPU memory bandwidth do we get with a sparse/dense matrix-vector multiply. Where is the break even point between compute/memory bandwidth for common operations like XtX and XY (with increasing number of columns for Y). 

3) The methods values(r), indexes(r) return the full arrays in order to avoid copy - together with pos(r) this allowed us to implement all sparse operations efficiently against CSR and MCSR at the same time. However, making it more explicitly is fine; I would recommend to follow the same pattern and call them values() and indexes().

This is awesome!!
Very welcome addition/upgrade to the way SystemML can be used from Apache Spark.
Thank you @dusenberrymw and @nakul02!
Argh, there were still some hardcoded *_2.10 dependencies left. Should be fixed now

@niketanpansare This is great!  I'm definitely in favor of creating a Python DSL.  Here are my thoughts on the proposed questions:
1. What is preferred usage scenario for a Python data scientist ?
   a. Scikit-learn like-library. In this case, we can call the DML algorithms using MLContext.
   b. External DSL approach: The data scientists will write her code in PyDML and then use MLContext.
   **c. Embedded DSL approach.**  This is where we need to move to if we want data scientists to start using the project since they will want to write code in Python itself.
2. Even in embedded DSL approach, there are two possible implementation choices:
   a. Execute code with a context (as in this PR). 
   Pros: Simple and elegant push-down mechanism and no redundant computation.
   Cons: Difficult to implement mixed code.
   **b. Add lazy data structures which will be executed only when certain actions are invoked on them.**  Ideally, we will want the user to be able to mix in NumPy and other Python code seamlessly.  Option (a) is still a decent approach.
3. Push-down of language-level constructs:
   **a. No modification to Python implementation, but slightly inelegant usage through use of functions (as in this PR). See parfor invocation in the below code.**  We definitely do _not_ want to ask the user to create a custom Python build.  We should simply support PySpark with Python 2 or 3.
   b. Modify Python parser to support pushdown. This requires users to rebuilt oru version of python from scratch.
4. Whether to add standalone support as it requires reimplementing Py4J bridge of PySpark.  **No, using PySpark on a laptop is already extremely simple.**
5. APIs of the built-in functions: Should it be similar to PyDML ? **I would vote for it to be equivalent to NumPy.**

Thanks @dusenberrymw for your thoughts :+1: 

Here are my comments:

> > **Add lazy data structures which will be executed only when certain actions are invoked on them. Option (a) is still a decent approach.**

My only worry with Option (2.b) is that adding lazy data structure would make Python API complex and hence make the embedded script difficult to debug. We can start by getting feedback about Option (2.a) from data scientists and go to Option (2.b) only if absolutely necessary.

> > **Push-down of language-level constructs**

I agree with you about Option (3a). Also, cleaned up the API for language-level constructs (and updated the example in my first comment). So Option (3.b) is not required.

> > **Ideally, we will want the user to be able to mix in NumPy and other Python code seamlessly.** 

There are two options here:

A. We ask users to isolate the mixed code themselves:

``` python
with context(sqlCtx):
    m1 = random.uniform(rows=3, cols=2)
    m2 = random.normal(rows=2, cols=3)
    m3 = dot(m1, m2)
    registerOutput([m3])

# mixed code:
numpyM3 = m3.getNumPyArray()
numpyM4 = do certain numpy operations
m4 = Matrix(numpyM4)

with context(sqlCtx):
    some DML that uses m4
```

The above option requires writing appropriate input/output wrappers to convert binary blocked RDD into NumPy arrays and viceversa.

B. We do callbacks to Python using external builtin functions. Here the user will have to wrap up mixed code into Python UDF and then we provide some construct to push it down as external UDF. The external UDF will do necessary conversions and call Python UDF using Py4J framework.

Thanks Imran. This is awesome !! May be later, we can create an ipython notebook that guides a new user using "Merck Visualization Challenge": https://www.kaggle.com/c/MerckActivity/prospector#186 :+1:

I like the idea of writing everything in python. My suggestion would be to make the API more python like, so that for a python user it doesn't feel unnatural. I would like the syntax to be something like the following, but I don't know if it is technically possible.

``` python
import numpy as np
import SystemML as sml
from pyspark.sql import SQLContext

mlContext = MLContext(sc)

m1 = sml.full(1, rows=3, cols=3)
m1 = m1 + 1

tmp = np.ones((3,3))  # numpy matrix
m2 = sml.matrix(tmp)  # ability to convert numpy to systemml matrix (???)
m2 += 2
m3 = m1 * m2
m3 /= m1
m1 = sml.random.uniform(rows=3, cols=2)
m2 = sml.random.normal(rows=2, cols=3)
m4 = sml.dot(m1, m2)

mlContext.registerOutput([m3, m4])
mlContext.execute()

m3.getDF().show()
m4.getDF().show()
```

There are also new deprecation compiler warnings that can be addressed in separate JIRA/PR subtask.  The LogisticRegression wrapper API classes may also need separate investigation since only generated default implementations for new abstract methods.

The intent with this PR was to establish an initial baseline with Spark 2.0.0.  Handling previous versions of Spark can be discussed separately (e.g., dev list) since some Spark changes are not backward compatible.  One possible option would be to use recently created 0.10 Maintenance branch for Spark versions < 2.0.0.
